content.text: What Wants to Kill You

“Threat classification is provided as a courtesy to contracting personnel. Actual threat levels may vary. Intercompany Contractor Relations assumes no responsibility for encounters exceeding projected difficulty. If you are reading this after dying, please disregard.“
Building enemies should be fast. If it takes longer to stat a creature than it does to fight it, something’s wrong.

Most fights should resolve in 2-4 rounds. Arcane Steel combat is fast and dangerous — both ways. Enemies that take 10 rounds to grind down aren’t scary, they’re boring. Even bosses should feel urgent, not padded.

The framework: Pick a Threat Tier (how dangerous), pick a Role (how it fights), adjust numbers, add 1-2 special abilities if needed. That’s it. You should be able to build an encounter-ready enemy in under 2 minutes.
Every enemy has a Threat Tier that sets its baseline stats. This is the rough power level — not a level system, just a shorthand for “how much can this thing hurt the players.“
Threat Tier Description Typical Source
T1 — Fodder Weak individually. Common rift fauna, Dangerous in groups. street thugs, Die fast. malfunctioning drones, wildlife
T2 — Competent A real fight Trained guards, one-on-one. Skilled or mid-tier rift tough enough to matter. creatures, rival contractors, predators
T3 — Dangerous Serious threat. Players Elite corp security, should respect them. apex rift predators, experienced rival teams, rift anomalies

T4 — Nightmare Campaign-level threats. Rift lords, corporate Plan before engaging. kill teams, dimensional horrors, things that shouldn’t exist ----------------------- ----------------------- -----------------------
Baseline Stats by Tier
Stat T1 Fodder T2 T3 T4 Competent Dangerous Nightmare
Evasion 3-4 4-5 5-7 6-8
Armor 0-1 1-3 2-5 4-7
Accuracy 2d4 or 1d6 2d6 or 2d8 2d8 or 3d8 3d10 or 2d12 Dice
Damage 1d4 1d6 or 1d8 2d6 or 2d8 2d10 or 3d8

Use the ranges. A tough T2 might have 18 HP and Armor 3 (a tank). A fast T2 might have 10 HP, Evasion 5, and Armor 1 (a skirmisher). The tier sets the power budget — you distribute it based on the creature’s role.
Roles define how an enemy fights. Each role adjusts the baseline stats in a specific direction and suggests tactical behavior.
Brute

High HP, high damage, low Evasion. Walks toward you and hits hard. Simple AI: move to nearest target, attack. Doesn’t dodge, doesn’t retreat. The thing you need to drop before it reaches the backline.
Stat Adjustments: +50% HP. +1 damage die. -1 Evasion. Armor +1.
Behavior: Moves toward nearest target every round. Prioritizes the closest enemy. Doesn’t disengage willingly.
Use for: Rift beasts, augmented enforcers, gene-spliced monstrosities, anything big and angry.
Skirmisher
High Evasion, moderate damage, low HP. Fast, annoying, hits and moves. Forces players to chase or ignore (and get flanked). Dies quickly when caught.
Stat Adjustments: -30% HP. +2 Evasion. Speed: moves 2 range bands per turn instead of 1.
Behavior: Attacks then repositions. Targets isolated or vulnerable characters. Retreats when below 50% HP.
Use for: Rift stalkers, assassin drones, flanking predators, fast melee creatures, scouts.
Artillery
High damage at range, fragile up close. Sits in the back and shoots. If players close the gap, it folds. The incentive to push forward instead of trading shots.
Stat Adjustments: -30% HP. -1 Evasion. Ranged attacks only (Close to Long range). +2 accuracy at Medium+ range.
Behavior: Maintains maximum range. Targets lowest-Armor players. Retreats if enemies reach Adjacent.
Use for: Rift spitters, corp snipers, turrets, magic-slinging anomalies, ranged predators.
Tank
Very high HP and Armor, low damage. Exists to block, absorb, and protect other enemies. Not a threat alone — dangerous because it wastes your time while its allies kill you.
Stat Adjustments: +100% HP. +2 Armor. -2 accuracy. Damage dice -1 size (d8 → d6, d6 → d4).
Behavior: Positions between players and high-value enemies. Uses body to block movement. Doesn’t chase — holds ground.
Use for: Rift beasts with shells, shield-bearing guards, armored drones, living walls.
Swarm / Horde
Many weak units acting as one. Uses the Horde rules from Combat. Single activation, single roll, bonuses from group size. Shrinks as members die.
Stat Adjustments: Use T1 baseline for individual members. Add Horde size bonuses per Combat rules. Individual members have 1-4 HP each.
Behavior: Rushes the nearest target as a mass. Splits to surround if possible.
Use for: Rift vermin, insect swarms, drone clouds, zombie hordes, swarming parasites.
Quick Horde Reference:
Horde Size Bonus Bonus Individual Total Group Accuracy Damage HP HP
Controller
Applies conditions and manipulates the battlefield. Not about raw damage — about making the fight harder for players through debuffs, forced movement, terrain effects, or disabling abilities.
Stat Adjustments: Standard HP. Moderate damage. Has 1-2 control abilities instead of raw damage output.
Behavior: Stays at medium range. Targets the most effective player (highest damage dealer, the healer, whoever is carrying the mission). Uses control abilities first, attacks second.
Use for: Rift psionics, techno-mages, support drones, creatures with grapple/web/toxin abilities, enemy channelers.
Most T1 enemies don’t need special abilities — their stats are their identity. T2+ enemies benefit from 1-2 abilities that make them memorable and tactically distinct.
Pick from the menu or invent your own. These are examples, not an exhaustive list.
Offensive Abilities
Ability Effect Good For
Multiattack Makes 2 attacks per Brutes, Skirmishers activation (split between targets).
Cleave If attack kills a Brutes target, excess damage carries to an Adjacent ally.
Pounce If moved 2+ range bands Skirmishers this turn, +2 accuracy on first attack.
Venomous Attacks apply 1 Poison Rift fauna, Skirmishers stack on hit.
Explosive Death When killed, deals 1d6 Swarms, suicide units damage to all Adjacent creatures.
Charging Strike Moves full speed and Brutes attacks in one action. +1 damage die if moved 2+ bands.
Magic Lash Ranged attack (Close Controllers, Rift range) that adds +1 creatures Toxicity to the target.
Grab On hit, target is Brutes, Tanks Grappled (must spend 1 AP to escape, Chrome DC 6).
Pack Tactics +1 accuracy if an ally Any group enemies is Adjacent to the target. ----------------------- ----------------------- -----------------------

Ability Effect Good For
Regeneration Heals 1d4 HP at the Tanks, Brutes, Rift start of its turn. creatures State what stops it (fire, magic, acid).
Armor Plating First hit each round Tanks deals 0 damage (bounces off). Subsequent hits resolve normally.

Ability Effect Good For
Terrifying Presence On first appearance, Bosses, T3+ creatures all players must check Grit DC 6 or lose their first action (hesitation).

Roar / Shriek All Adjacent enemies Brutes, Bosses take -1 accuracy for 1 round. Once per encounter.

Bosses break the rules. They’re the centerpiece of an encounter — the thing the whole fight is about.
Boss Template
Take a T3 or T4 baseline and add:
Multiple Activations: Bosses get 2-3 activations per round, maintaining turn parity with the players. A boss with 3 activations in a 4-player fight means you only need 1 additional enemy to match.

Condition Resistance: Bosses reduce all condition stacks by 1 at the end of each of their activations (not each round — each activation). This prevents a single effect-weapon user from locking them down entirely. Stacking still works, it just requires sustained effort.
Threshold Abilities: Bosses gain new abilities or change behavior at HP thresholds. This prevents the fight from feeling static.
HP Threshold Trigger
75% Minor escalation. New attack pattern, summon adds, reveal a weakness.
50% Major escalation. New ability, environmental change, phase shift.
25% Desperation. Damage increases, defense drops, or a dangerous “final form“ ability triggers. ----------------------------------- -----------------------------------
Example Boss: Rift Stalker Alpha (T3 Boss)
Stat Value
HP                                  60
Evasion                             6
Armor                               3
Accuracy                            3d8 (melee), 2d8 (ranged spit)
Damage                              2d8 melee, 1d10 + Poison ranged
Activations                         3

Thresholds: • 75% (45 HP): Lets out a Shriek. All Adjacent players -1 accuracy for 2 rounds. Calls 1d4 T1 rift stalkers. • 50% (30 HP): Phase Shift — disappears for 1 round. Repositions anywhere on the battlefield. Next attack from stealth: +4 accuracy. • 25% (15 HP): Frenzy — gains Multiattack. Now making 2 attacks per activation (6 attacks per round total). Evasion drops to 4 (reckless).
Activation Budget
The core rule: enemy activations should roughly equal player count.
Players Target Activations Example Compositions
3                       3                       3 Standards / 1 Boss(2) + 1 Standard / 1 Elite + 1 Horde + 1 Standard
4                       4                       4 Standards / 1 Boss(3) + 1 Horde / 2 Elites + 2 Standards
Going 1 over or under is fine. Going 2+ over makes the fight feel unfair. Going 2+ under makes it trivial.
Threat Budget
Beyond activations, the total enemy HP and damage output should match the encounter’s intended difficulty.
Quick Math — Total Enemy HP by Difficulty:
Difficulty Total Enemy Rounds to Feel HP Resolve
Easy 2-3× total party 1-2 rounds Quick. Warm-up. damage per round Costs resources but no real danger.
Standard 3-5× total party 2-4 rounds A real fight. damage per round Someone probably takes a hit. Scars possible.
Hard 5-8× total party 3-5 rounds Dangerous. Scars damage per round likely. Resource drain. Players should feel the cost.

Deadly 8-12× total party 4-6 rounds Someone might damage per round die. Multiple scars. Major resource expenditure. Save these for climactic moments. ----------------- ----------------- ----------------- -----------------
Estimating party damage per round: Each player deals roughly 8-15 damage per round at early levels, 15-25 mid-campaign, 25-40 late-campaign. Multiply by player count for total party damage per round.
Encounter Types
The Quick Fight (1-2 rounds)

Most fights should be this. Contractors encounter 3-4 T1-T2 enemies, crush them quickly, and move on. The fight costs resources (HP, Charges, maybe a consumable) but doesn’t threaten death. These are the tax of doing business — the rift fauna between you and the objective.
Design: Low total HP. Moderate damage. No special abilities needed. Resolve fast, move on.
The Real Fight (3-4 rounds)

The set-piece encounter. Players face a tactical challenge — mixed enemy types, environmental hazards, or a single tough enemy that requires coordination. Someone’s probably taking a Scar if they’re careless.

Design: Mixed roles. At least one enemy with a special ability. Terrain matters. Players should need to make tactical decisions (focus fire vs spread, push forward vs hold, use consumables or save them).
The Boss Fight (4-6 rounds)

The climactic encounter. One major threat (possibly with adds) that requires the full team working together. Boss threshold abilities shift the fight’s dynamics. Resource management is critical — this is where stockpiled consumables and crafted ammo pay off.

Design: Boss with 2-3 activations + 1-2 support enemies. Threshold abilities at 75/50/25%. Environmental element (the rift is closing, the room is flooding, reinforcements are coming in X rounds). Victory should feel earned.
The Survival Gauntlet

Not one fight — a series of encounters with limited rest between them. 3-4 quick fights back to back, each individually easy but cumulatively draining. This is where the resource economy shines — players who conserved Charges and Med Patches survive. Players who went nova on fight 1 suffer by fight 4.
Design: Multiple Easy encounters with short breathers between. No chance to rest/heal fully. Final encounter should be Standard or Hard difficulty while the party is already depleted.
Use this template for prep. Keep it to index-card size — if it doesn’t fit on a card, it’s too complex.

HP: 12 \| Evasion: 4 \| Armor: 3 Attack: 2d6 accuracy → 1d8 damage/hit (rifle, ranged) Stat Bonus: +1 Activations: 1 Special: Pack Tactics (+1 accuracy if ally adjacent to target) Behavior: Takes cover. Fires from range. Calls for backup if outnumbered. Loot: Corp Rifle (damaged, 50% market value), Standard Rounds ×2
Rift Broodmother — Brute T3

HP: 45 \| Evasion: 4 \| Armor: 4 Attack: 2d10 accuracy → 2d10 damage/hit (claws) Stat Bonus: +3 Activations: 2 Special: Cleave (excess kill damage carries to adjacent). Summon (once per encounter, calls 1d6 T1 rift hounds). Behavior: Charges highest-Chrome target. Summons pups when first bloodied (50% HP). Loot: Broodmother carapace (T3 material), venom sacs ×2 (T2 material), brood gland (T3 material — worth 3× if preserved)
Dimensional Rift Horror — Controller T4

HP: 70 \| Evasion: 7 \| Armor: 3 Attack: 3d8 accuracy → 2d8 damage/hit (reality tendrils, Close range) Stat Bonus: +5 Activations: 3 Special: Toxicity Aura (Adjacent +1 Toxicity/round). Dimensional Anchor (target can’t move 1 round, +1 Toxicity). Phase Shift (once per encounter, untargetable 1 round). Terrifying Presence. Behavior: Stays at Close range. Anchors the highest-damage player. Uses tendrils on everyone else. Phase Shifts when below 50%. Loot: Dimensional essence (T4 material — extremely valuable, extremely dangerous to carry) Threshold 75%: Tendrils extend — can now attack at Medium range. Threshold 50%: Phase Shift + reposition. Toxicity Aura radius increases to Close. Threshold 25%: Reality Tear — all players in Close range take 2d6 unresistable damage and +2 Toxicity. One-time blast.
